2/ The Ask 

Hydro is requesting 7M ATOM from the community pool to deposit into their Inflow vault. The ATOM will be deployed into low-risk DeFi strategies to generate yield.

Important: The principal stays as ATOM and can be clawed back anytime by governance.

3/ Zero-Fee LST 

Hydro will build a Hub-native ATOM LST with zero fees, unlike stATOM and dATOM which charge 10% on staking yield.

While it might not seem big, over time it adds up. After five years, avoiding fees results in 8.87% more ATOM. That's huge for institutions.

4/ Built for Institutions 

The LST is designed for institutional stakers with features they need:

 Vote on Hub proposals while deployed in DeFi
 Tax-efficient auto-compounding
 Peg stability mechanisms
 Liquid Staking Module support

5/ Governance Rights 

Institutions can stake ATOM, earn DeFi yield, and still participate in Hub governance.

Hydro will tally votes from LST holders and cast a weighted vote from the contract without impacting quorum.

6/ Beyond Cosmos 

The team will leverage the ATOM diaspora (Cosmos teams now building on other chains) to integrate the LST across major DeFi protocols.

Think lending markets, DEXs, and perps on EVM chains where ATOM isn't available yet.

7/ The Inflow Integration 

LST holders can deposit into Hydro's ATOM Inflow vault to earn additional DeFi yield. Three lock durations: 1 day, 24 days, and 90 days.

Longer locks = higher yield as funds deploy into more advanced strategies.

8/ Yield Strategies 

The vault uses delta-neutral strategies:

 LST redemption arbitrage
 Leveraged staking
 Funding rate farming & arbitrage
 Borrow/lend arbitrage
 Fixed-rate yield primitives
 LPing (ATOM/ATOM LST)

All designed to minimize risk.

9/ Where Yield Goes 

Hydro estimates $150k/month needed for development (3 new devs, 4-5 audits, integrations).

Any yield above that? Straight to ATOM burns.

This directly reduces circulating supply and creates upward price pressure (if yield > $150k ofc)

10/ Non-Inflationary Yield 

Many strategies generate yield without relying on ATOM inflation. For example, LST redemption arbitrage captures the spread when LSTs trade below their redemption value.

As ATOM inflation reduces, this becomes even more critical.

11/ The dATOM Option 

Hydro is exploring taking over maintenance of dATOM from Drop and migrating it to the Hub.

Existing dATOM holders would get a seamless migration path, but this isn't required. Hydro will build the new LST either way.

12/ Security First 

The LST will use 
@informalinc
 specification language for formal verification. Validators will follow Cosmos Labs' delegation framework.

Minting caps prevent large holders from attacking the peg through mass sell-offs.

14/ Governance Control 

Hub governance controls all Hydro DAOs through nested 
@DA0_DA0
 structure. A simple proposal can claw back the entire deposit or any portion of it at any time.

The community pool funds never leave governance's control.

15/ Migration to the Hub 

Hydro will migrate all existing contracts to the Hub. This positions the Hub as the center of a new DeFi ecosystem ready for institutional assets.

Stocks, bonds, treasuries, commodities all need DeFi protocols to generate yield.

16/ CEX Integration 

Through 
@WAVS_WAVS_WAVS
 integration, users can transfer ATOM staked on centralized exchanges directly to the LST for higher yield.

This moves ATOM from exchange validators to community validators and increases governance participation.

17/ Burn Projections 

Hydro's projections account for inflation reduction, ATOM price increases, and LST adoption.

They assume partial clawbacks over time as community funds may be reallocated if higher-priority needs arise.

18/ Aligned Incentives 

Hydro has no token and hasn't raised external capital. They operate on yield from ATOM deployments.

If the LST succeeds, both Hydro and the Hub win. If it fails, governance can claw back funds and Hydro would wind down.

19/ The Bottom Line 

7M ATOM generates DeFi yield → funds zero-fee institutional LST development → excess yield burns ATOM → governance keeps full control.

This could be a game-changer for ATOM's value accrual and institutional positioning.

2/ The enterprise reality 

Fortune 500 companies, multinational banks, and governments are already using the Cosmos SDK or have expressed interest in working with Cosmos Labs.

Regulatory changes around stablecoins and payments are driving this adoption.

3/ The big problem 

ATOM is stuck in a staking-only circular utility model. Meanwhile, massive enterprise adoption of Cosmos SDK is happening, but $ATOM doesn't capture that value.

This RFP aims to fix that disconnect.

4/ The new vision 

$ATOM will become the medium by which anyone can get exposure to the network effects of broader Cosmos SDK adoption by enterprises, banks, and governments.

No longer just staking rewards from inflation.

5/ Revenue-driven model 

The redesign centers around a new fee model based on on-chain and off-chain revenue sources.

Think enterprise contracts, SDK usage fees, IBC Eureka routing fees, and more feeding value back to $ATOM holders.

6/ Current state snapshot 

→ 10% inflation rate
→ 58% bonding ratio (target 66%)
→ 16.9% staking APR
→ Interchain Security being deprecated
→ Prop 848 (inflation cut) passed by only 3% margin

Stakeholders are sensitive to changes.

7/ Three-phase approach 

Phase 1: Research and Audit - understand current dynamics, stakeholder analysis, comparable networks

Phase 2: Analytics and Modeling - simulate scenarios, validate with data

Phase 3: Community Activation - governance proposals

8/ What gets studied 

Research firms will analyze where ATOM buy/sell pressure comes from, model enterprise revenue potential, evaluate inflation cut scenarios, simulate validator economics, and design a transition plan with stakeholder mitigations.

9/ Not from scratch 

This isn't a first-principles redesign. The constraint is clear: build a revenue-driven model that synergizes various ATOM revenue sources with updates to supply dynamics and inflation.

Practical, not theoretical.

10/ Timeline and next steps 

Proposals due January 15, 2026. Multiple research firms will likely be selected to compete with the best ideas.

After research and modeling, the community votes on governance proposals to implement changes.

11/ The bottom line 

Cosmos SDK is winning with enterprises. ATOM's tokenomics need to evolve from circular inflation to capturing real ecosystem value.

If executed right, ATOM becomes the equity of the Cosmos Stack.

The future is being designed now.

1/ Cosmos Hub December Report

The Hub Unit just dropped their latest monthly update on and there's some progress happening behind the scenes.

→ ICF delegation changes
→ Stargaze migration
→ Tokenfactory testing
→ $ATOM Tokenomics RFP updates.

A thread

2/
The guiding principle for 2025–2026 is simple:

“Earn the right to scale — then scale.”
That means real improvements in throughput, block times, stability, interoperability, and enterprise-grade features.

3/
 What shipped in 2025

Cosmos Labs brought core stack development back in-house and cleaned up years of complexity. Priorities were clear: easier upgrades, simpler IBC, and a native EVM.

4/
Key 2025 releases:

• Cosmos SDK v0.53 — seamless upgrades (as little as 2 lines of code changed)

• IBC v2 (ibc-go v10) — simpler protocol, easier to implement anywhere

• IBC to Ethereum via Solidity & CosmWasm light clients

5/
 Cosmos EVM

Cosmos Labs acquired, open-sourced, and hardened a native EVM:

• Security-audited releases

• True EVM mempool

• Account abstraction (EIP-7702)
Already used by Ripple, MANTRA, Telegram/TAC, KiiChain & more.

6/
With foundations set, 2026 is about acceleration.

 Global performance targets:

• 5,000 TPS sustained in production

• 500ms block times

• Stability under heavy & adversarial load

7/
 Performance upgrades underway

• BlockSTM for parallel execution

• Fully concurrent ABCI

• Major CometBFT networking improvements

• Massive storage rewrite: IAVLX

8/
 IAVLX (IAVL rewrite)

Early results:

• Up to 30x faster writes

• Commit times ~20ms (vs ~150ms spikes)

• ~25,000 ops/sec

• Stable memory (<2GB)
Designed for speed, scalability, and lower node costs.

9/
 Connectivity: IBC everywhere

Cosmos is expanding IBC beyond Cosmos chains to:

• 
@ethereum
• 
@solana
• EVM L2s

• Any VM or enterprise system

10/
New connectivity primitives:

• IBC Attestor Light Clients (for chains without native light clients)

• Solana & EVM/L2 support

• GMP (General Message Passing)

• IFT (Interchain Fungible Token) — mint/burn model, no path-dependent denoms

11/
 Enterprise-grade features

A major milestone: Native Proof of Authority (PoA) built directly into the Cosmos SDK — no staking token, no hacks.

12/
PoA enables:

• Token-free permissioned networks

• Migration path from PoA → PoS

• Token-free governance

• Validator rewards without staking complexity

Targeted for Cosmos SDK v0.54 (H1 2026).

13/
 Programmable Privacy

Cosmos Labs evaluated TEE, FHE, and ZK approaches.

For 2026, the most promising path is ZK-based UTXO privacy, enabled by PoA and selective disclosure for compliance.

14/
 Developer & ecosystem changes

Non-core modules (NFTs, Groups, Circuit, Crisis) move to /contrib, keeping the core lean while empowering community ownership.

15/
 Major releases ahead

• Q1–Q2: CometBFT v0.39, SDK v0.54, ibc-go v11

• Q2: IBC GMP, IFT, Solana & EVM/L2 support

• Q3: libp2p networking in production

• Q4: 5,000 TPS & 500ms blocks in production

16/
 Security

Cosmos Labs now runs the bug bounty program:

• $465k paid out

• 24 confirmed vulnerabilities

• Coverage expanded to Cosmos EVM
Security remains a top priority as enterprise adoption grows.

17/
 Collaboration matters

Major contributions from 
@MANTRA_Chain
, 
@cronos_chain
, B-Harvest, Binary Builders, Informal Systems & others are helping push Cosmos performance and interoperability forward.

18/
 Looking ahead

Cosmos is positioning itself as a long-term, enterprise-grade, high-performance blockchain stack — scalable, interoperable, and production-ready.

19/
If you’re building financial infrastructure, enterprise networks, or multichain apps — Cosmos 2026 is built for you.

20/
End of thread 
Follow 
@cosmoslabs_io
 for updates, releases, and performance benchmarks.

2/ The Ask 

Hydro is requesting 7M ATOM from the community pool to deposit into their Inflow vault. The ATOM will be deployed into low-risk DeFi strategies to generate yield.

Important: The principal stays as ATOM and can be clawed back anytime by governance.

3/ Zero-Fee LST 

Hydro will build a Hub-native ATOM LST with zero fees, unlike stATOM and dATOM which charge 10% on staking yield.

While it might not seem big, over time it adds up. After five years, avoiding fees results in 8.87% more ATOM. That's huge for institutions.

4/ Built for Institutions 

The LST is designed for institutional stakers with features they need:

 Vote on Hub proposals while deployed in DeFi
 Tax-efficient auto-compounding
 Peg stability mechanisms
 Liquid Staking Module support

5/ Governance Rights 

Institutions can stake ATOM, earn DeFi yield, and still participate in Hub governance.

Hydro will tally votes from LST holders and cast a weighted vote from the contract without impacting quorum.

6/ Beyond Cosmos 

The team will leverage the ATOM diaspora (Cosmos teams now building on other chains) to integrate the LST across major DeFi protocols.

Think lending markets, DEXs, and perps on EVM chains where ATOM isn't available yet.

7/ The Inflow Integration 

LST holders can deposit into Hydro's ATOM Inflow vault to earn additional DeFi yield. Three lock durations: 1 day, 24 days, and 90 days.

Longer locks = higher yield as funds deploy into more advanced strategies.

8/ Yield Strategies 

The vault uses delta-neutral strategies:

 LST redemption arbitrage
 Leveraged staking
 Funding rate farming & arbitrage
 Borrow/lend arbitrage
 Fixed-rate yield primitives
 LPing (ATOM/ATOM LST)

All designed to minimize risk.

9/ Where Yield Goes 

Hydro estimates $150k/month needed for development (3 new devs, 4-5 audits, integrations).

Any yield above that? Straight to ATOM burns.

This directly reduces circulating supply and creates upward price pressure (if yield > $150k ofc)

10/ Non-Inflationary Yield 

Many strategies generate yield without relying on ATOM inflation. For example, LST redemption arbitrage captures the spread when LSTs trade below their redemption value.

As ATOM inflation reduces, this becomes even more critical.

11/ The dATOM Option 

Hydro is exploring taking over maintenance of dATOM from Drop and migrating it to the Hub.

Existing dATOM holders would get a seamless migration path, but this isn't required. Hydro will build the new LST either way.

12/ Security First 

The LST will use 
@informalinc
 specification language for formal verification. Validators will follow Cosmos Labs' delegation framework.

Minting caps prevent large holders from attacking the peg through mass sell-offs.

14/ Governance Control 

Hub governance controls all Hydro DAOs through nested 
@DA0_DA0
 structure. A simple proposal can claw back the entire deposit or any portion of it at any time.

The community pool funds never leave governance's control.

15/ Migration to the Hub 

Hydro will migrate all existing contracts to the Hub. This positions the Hub as the center of a new DeFi ecosystem ready for institutional assets.

Stocks, bonds, treasuries, commodities all need DeFi protocols to generate yield.

16/ CEX Integration 

Through 
@WAVS_WAVS_WAVS
 integration, users can transfer ATOM staked on centralized exchanges directly to the LST for higher yield.

This moves ATOM from exchange validators to community validators and increases governance participation.

17/ Burn Projections 

Hydro's projections account for inflation reduction, ATOM price increases, and LST adoption.

They assume partial clawbacks over time as community funds may be reallocated if higher-priority needs arise.

18/ Aligned Incentives 

Hydro has no token and hasn't raised external capital. They operate on yield from ATOM deployments.

If the LST succeeds, both Hydro and the Hub win. If it fails, governance can claw back funds and Hydro would wind down.

19/ The Bottom Line 

7M ATOM generates DeFi yield → funds zero-fee institutional LST development → excess yield burns ATOM → governance keeps full control.

This could be a game-changer for ATOM's value accrual and institutional positioning.

2/ The enterprise reality 

Fortune 500 companies, multinational banks, and governments are already using the Cosmos SDK or have expressed interest in working with Cosmos Labs.

Regulatory changes around stablecoins and payments are driving this adoption.

3/ The big problem 

ATOM is stuck in a staking-only circular utility model. Meanwhile, massive enterprise adoption of Cosmos SDK is happening, but $ATOM doesn't capture that value.

This RFP aims to fix that disconnect.

4/ The new vision 

$ATOM will become the medium by which anyone can get exposure to the network effects of broader Cosmos SDK adoption by enterprises, banks, and governments.

No longer just staking rewards from inflation.

5/ Revenue-driven model 

The redesign centers around a new fee model based on on-chain and off-chain revenue sources.

Think enterprise contracts, SDK usage fees, IBC Eureka routing fees, and more feeding value back to $ATOM holders.

6/ Current state snapshot 

→ 10% inflation rate
→ 58% bonding ratio (target 66%)
→ 16.9% staking APR
→ Interchain Security being deprecated
→ Prop 848 (inflation cut) passed by only 3% margin

Stakeholders are sensitive to changes.

7/ Three-phase approach 

Phase 1: Research and Audit - understand current dynamics, stakeholder analysis, comparable networks

Phase 2: Analytics and Modeling - simulate scenarios, validate with data

Phase 3: Community Activation - governance proposals

8/ What gets studied 

Research firms will analyze where ATOM buy/sell pressure comes from, model enterprise revenue potential, evaluate inflation cut scenarios, simulate validator economics, and design a transition plan with stakeholder mitigations.

9/ Not from scratch 

This isn't a first-principles redesign. The constraint is clear: build a revenue-driven model that synergizes various ATOM revenue sources with updates to supply dynamics and inflation.

Practical, not theoretical.

10/ Timeline and next steps 

Proposals due January 15, 2026. Multiple research firms will likely be selected to compete with the best ideas.

After research and modeling, the community votes on governance proposals to implement changes.

11/ The bottom line 

Cosmos SDK is winning with enterprises. ATOM's tokenomics need to evolve from circular inflation to capturing real ecosystem value.

If executed right, ATOM becomes the equity of the Cosmos Stack.

1/ Cosmos Hub December Report

The Hub Unit just dropped their latest monthly update on and there's some progress happening behind the scenes.

→ ICF delegation changes
→ Stargaze migration
→ Tokenfactory testing
→ $ATOM Tokenomics RFP updates.

A thread

2/
The guiding principle for 2025–2026 is simple:

“Earn the right to scale — then scale.”
That means real improvements in throughput, block times, stability, interoperability, and enterprise-grade features.

3/
 What shipped in 2025

Cosmos Labs brought core stack development back in-house and cleaned up years of complexity. Priorities were clear: easier upgrades, simpler IBC, and a native EVM.

4/
Key 2025 releases:

• Cosmos SDK v0.53 — seamless upgrades (as little as 2 lines of code changed)

• IBC v2 (ibc-go v10) — simpler protocol, easier to implement anywhere

• IBC to Ethereum via Solidity & CosmWasm light clients

5/
 Cosmos EVM

Cosmos Labs acquired, open-sourced, and hardened a native EVM:

• Security-audited releases

• True EVM mempool

• Account abstraction (EIP-7702)
Already used by Ripple, MANTRA, Telegram/TAC, KiiChain & more.

6/
With foundations set, 2026 is about acceleration.

 Global performance targets:

• 5,000 TPS sustained in production

• 500ms block times

• Stability under heavy & adversarial load

7/
 Performance upgrades underway

• BlockSTM for parallel execution

• Fully concurrent ABCI

• Major CometBFT networking improvements

• Massive storage rewrite: IAVLX

8/
 IAVLX (IAVL rewrite)

Early results:

• Up to 30x faster writes

• Commit times ~20ms (vs ~150ms spikes)

• ~25,000 ops/sec

• Stable memory (<2GB)
Designed for speed, scalability, and lower node costs.

9/
 Connectivity: IBC everywhere

Cosmos is expanding IBC beyond Cosmos chains to:

• 
@ethereum
• 
@solana
• EVM L2s

• Any VM or enterprise system

10/
New connectivity primitives:

• IBC Attestor Light Clients (for chains without native light clients)

• Solana & EVM/L2 support

• GMP (General Message Passing)

• IFT (Interchain Fungible Token) — mint/burn model, no path-dependent denoms

11/
 Enterprise-grade features

A major milestone: Native Proof of Authority (PoA) built directly into the Cosmos SDK — no staking token, no hacks.

12/
PoA enables:

• Token-free permissioned networks

• Migration path from PoA → PoS

• Token-free governance

• Validator rewards without staking complexity

Targeted for Cosmos SDK v0.54 (H1 2026).

13/
 Programmable Privacy

Cosmos Labs evaluated TEE, FHE, and ZK approaches.

For 2026, the most promising path is ZK-based UTXO privacy, enabled by PoA and selective disclosure for compliance.

14/
 Developer & ecosystem changes

Non-core modules (NFTs, Groups, Circuit, Crisis) move to /contrib, keeping the core lean while empowering community ownership.

15/
 Major releases ahead

• Q1–Q2: CometBFT v0.39, SDK v0.54, ibc-go v11

• Q2: IBC GMP, IFT, Solana & EVM/L2 support

• Q3: libp2p networking in production

• Q4: 5,000 TPS & 500ms blocks in production

16/
 Security

Cosmos Labs now runs the bug bounty program:

• $465k paid out

• 24 confirmed vulnerabilities

• Coverage expanded to Cosmos EVM
Security remains a top priority as enterprise adoption grows.

17/
 Collaboration matters

Major contributions from 
@MANTRA_Chain
, 
@cronos_chain
, B-Harvest, Binary Builders, Informal Systems & others are helping push Cosmos performance and interoperability forward.

18/
 Looking ahead

Cosmos is positioning itself as a long-term, enterprise-grade, high-performance blockchain stack — scalable, interoperable, and production-ready.

19/
If you’re building financial infrastructure, enterprise networks, or multichain apps — Cosmos 2026 is built for you.

20/
End of thread 
Follow 
@cosmoslabs_io
 for updates, releases, and performance benchmarks.
